field.name: General
field.description: Domain-general problems not specific to any particular field.

problems.title: Developer Burnout and Mounting Delivery Pressure in the AI Era
problems.description: Developer burnout has reached critical levels as enterprise expectations have increased alongside growing AI adoption. More than two-thirds of developers report mounting pressure to deliver projects faster, despite the productivity paradox where AI tools have not significantly reduced workload. The expectation that AI will accelerate everything has created unrealistic delivery timelines, with developers caught between using imperfect AI tools and meeting impossible deadlines. Context switching remains a major contributor, with developers rarely achieving flow states due to constant task-juggling across an average of 6+ different tools. Unrealistic deadlines force corner-cutting that creates technical debt, perpetuating a cycle of pressure. The software engineering job market has also become more volatile, with layoffs making news weekly and companies citing AI as justification, adding job security anxiety to existing stress factors.
problems.summary: Over two-thirds of developers face increased delivery pressure as AI adoption raises expectations. Context switching, tool sprawl, and unrealistic deadlines are driving burnout to critical levels.

neglectedness.fundingLevel: Limited - mostly addressed through HR programs

rootCauses.description: AI adoption creating unrealistic expectations for delivery velocity
Constant context switching across 6+ tools preventing deep focus
Job market volatility adding anxiety to work stress
Unrealistic deadlines forcing corner-cutting and quality compromises

consequences.description: Increased developer turnover and talent retention challenges
Reduced code quality as developers rush to meet unrealistic deadlines
Technical debt accumulation from corner-cutting under pressure
Industry-wide talent shortage as developers leave the profession

solutionGaps.description: Leadership training on realistic AI-era delivery expectations

problems.title: Software Engineering Talent Shortage and Skills Gap Crisis
problems.description: The software industry faces a persistent talent crisis that has worsened despite economic shifts. According to CompTIA's 2025 Workforce Trends report, 78% of companies report difficulty filling developer roles within 60 days. The shortage is particularly acute in specialized areas like AI/ML, cybersecurity, and DevOps. The share of AI/ML jobs in the tech market has increased from 10% to 50% between 2023 and 2025, creating intense competition for limited talent. Skills gaps have exacerbated problems as organizations need both experienced developers and those who can work effectively with AI tools. There's growing concern that newer engineers relying heavily on AI are not building fundamental skills, creating a potential long-term competency crisis. Organizations must invest in upgrading skills while being wary of overreliance on AI tools that can lead to stunted professional development.
problems.summary: 78% of companies cannot fill developer roles within 60 days. AI/ML job share grew from 10% to 50% (2023-2025), while concerns grow about junior developers not building fundamental skills.

barriers: Long training timelines for skilled developers
AI potentially stunting junior skill development

neglectedness.fundingLevel: High - major education and workforce investment

rootCauses.description: Rapid technology evolution outpacing educational pipeline
Exponential growth in demand for specialized skills (AI, security, cloud)
Junior developers over-relying on AI tools without building fundamentals
Inadequate investment in internal training and upskilling programs

consequences.description: 78% of companies struggle to fill developer roles within 60 days
Project delays due to understaffed teams
Salary inflation as companies compete for limited talent
Potential competency crisis as AI-reliant juniors enter senior roles

problems.title: Junior Developer Skill Erosion from AI Tool Over-Reliance
problems.description: A growing concern in software engineering is that junior developers relying too heavily on AI are not building fundamental skills, making them less competent long-term. Human code review has become an important bottleneck, with focus needed on decisions that cannot easily be generated away—like interface changes, data persistence, and performance-critical code. This creates a paradox for junior engineers: they need to develop 'review taste' earlier, but are doing less of the 'writing' that builds that intuition. With AI projected to handle 70-80% of routine coding tasks by 2026, the traditional learning path where juniors build skills through writing repetitive code is being disrupted. Organizations face a fundamental challenge of how to develop the next generation of senior engineers when the pathway that created current experts no longer exists in the same form.
problems.summary: Junior developers over-relying on AI are not building fundamental skills needed for senior roles. With AI handling 70-80% of routine coding, traditional skill development pathways are being disrupted.

barriers: Pressure to use AI for productivity
Unclear what fundamental skills remain essential
Limited research on AI-era skill development

neglectedness.fundingLevel: Limited - emerging concern without dedicated funding

rootCauses.description: AI automating the repetitive coding work that traditionally built junior skills
Organizational pressure to maximize AI productivity gains
Unclear frameworks for what skills remain essential in AI-augmented development
Traditional computer science education not adapting to AI-era needs

consequences.description: Junior developers lacking deep understanding of code they're using
Reduced ability to debug complex issues not solvable by AI
Potential future shortage of senior engineers with deep expertise
Organizations dependent on AI tools without human fallback capability

solutionGaps.opportunity: Hybrid curricula balancing AI tools with core engineering skills

problems.title: Unclear Requirements and Scope Creep Causing 37% of Project Failures
problems.description: Lack of clarity in project goals and requirements remains one of the top causes of project failure in software engineering, with about 37% of projects failing due to undefined objectives or unclear milestones. Software developers often work with less-than-complete understanding of business requirements established by business leaders and product owners, leading to misaligned goals, unnecessary features, and missed opportunities as developers focus on wrong priorities. Scope creep compounds the problem—65% of QA leaders cite late requirement changes as a top barrier, and business owners continuously request additional features or changes during development, leading to cost overruns and delays. With hybrid and distributed teams becoming common, misalignment is frequent; a 2025 project management survey notes that 55% of organizations lack real-time access to project KPIs, and cross-team disconnects remain a leading cause of delays.
problems.summary: 37% of projects fail due to unclear requirements. 65% of QA leaders cite late requirement changes as a top barrier, while 55% of organizations lack real-time access to project KPIs.

rootCauses.description: Business stakeholders unable or unwilling to fully articulate requirements upfront
Distributed and hybrid teams creating communication gaps
Pressure to start development before requirements are finalized
Lack of real-time project visibility tools and practices

consequences.description: 37% of projects fail due to undefined objectives or unclear milestones
Cost overruns and schedule delays from continuous scope changes
Developer frustration and rework from building wrong features
Technical debt from rushed implementations of late-added requirements

solutionGaps.description: Real-time requirement impact analysis for proposed changes
solutionGaps.opportunity: Systems that instantly show ripple effects of scope changes

stakeholders.description: Development teams building from unclear requirements
